introduction.title: Vietnamese Negation System
content: Vietnamese uses different negation words depending on the context and meaning. The three main forms are: không (general negation), không phải là (identity negation), and chưa (not yet/incomplete action).
Unlike English where 'not' is used universally, Vietnamese negation is more nuanced. Choosing the wrong negation word can completely change the meaning of a sentence.

The key distinction is between không (definite negation - 'I don't/won't') and chưa (implies possibility - 'I haven't... yet'). This distinction doesn't exist in English and is crucial for natural Vietnamese.

negationTypes.title: Không
negationTypes.subtitle: General Negation
negationTypes.description: The most common negation word in Vietnamese. Used to negate verbs, adjectives, and general statements. It expresses definite negation - something that is not happening, not true, or will not happen.
keyPoints: Placed directly before the verb or adjective
Works with both action verbs and stative verbs
Cannot be used alone with 'là' (use 'không phải là' instead)

examples.comparison: AFFIRMATIVE: Tôi thích ăn cá (I like eating fish)

examples.notes: Vietnamese doesn't need a separate 'to be' verb before adjectives

examples.vietnamese: Họ không làm việc vào cuối tuần

commonMistakes.right: Tôi không phải là học sinh
commonMistakes.explanation: Cannot use 'không' alone with 'là'. Must use 'không phải là' for identity negation.

negationTypes.title: Không Phải Là
negationTypes.subtitle: Identity/Classification Negation
negationTypes.description: Used specifically to negate identity, classification, or equations with the copula 'là' (to be). This is the Vietnamese equivalent of 'is not', 'are not', 'am not' when talking about what something IS.
keyPoints: Required when negating 'là' (to be) for identity
All three words must be used together

examples.vietnamese: Bạn không phải là giáo viên
examples.comparison: AFFIRMATIVE: Bạn là giáo viên (You are a teacher)

examples.vietnamese: Đây không phải là nhà tôi
Chúng ta không phải là bạn bè

commonMistakes.right: Tôi không phải là sinh viên
commonMistakes.explanation: Must use the full 'không phải là' phrase for identity negation.
'Không phải là' is only for identity with nouns, not for adjectives. Use plain 'không' for adjectives.

negationTypes.title: Chưa
negationTypes.subtitle: Not Yet / Incomplete Action
negationTypes.description: Expresses that an action has not happened YET, with the implication that it might happen in the future. This is fundamentally different from 'không' which is a definite negation.
keyPoints: Implies the action hasn't occurred but might/will occur
Different from 'không' which is definite negation
Often used in questions with implied 'rồi': 'Ăn cơm chưa?' (Have you eaten yet?)
Common in everyday greetings and questions

examples.vietnamese: Bố tôi chưa gọi cho tôi
examples.english: My dad hasn't called me yet
examples.literalEnglish: Father my not-yet call to me

examples.english: I haven't done the homework yet
examples.comparison: COMPARE: Tôi không làm bài tập (I don't/won't do homework - definite refusal)

examples.notes: Common Vietnamese greeting, literally asking about meals

commonMistakes.explanation: 'Chưa' is for actions/events, not states like 'liking'. Use 'không' for preferences and states.

comparisonTable.translation: I don't eat rice (I won't eat it)
comparisonTable.implication: Definite refusal or statement of fact

comparisonTable.meaning: is not / are not / am not
comparisonTable.example: Tôi không phải là bác sĩ

advancedNegations.example: Tôi không bao giờ nói dối
